docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Chateaubriand wrapped with mushroom duxelles and prosciutto, finished in puff pastry.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Recipe type: Beef Wellington
  • Cuisine: European
  • Prep time: 1-2 hours + overnight dry brine
  • Cook time: until pastry is golden and center reaches desired doneness
  • Total time: 1-2 days
  • Serves: 6-8
  • EGG setup: indirect
  • EGG target temperature: moderate baking heat

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Base:

  • 1 chateaubriand, dry brined with kosher salt overnight

Tallow injection:

  • 2 lb (900 g) ground beef fat
  • 10 whole garlic cloves
  • 4 roasted chestnuts, ground
  • 8 dried truffles
  • 3 sprigs fresh thyme
  • 4 cups water

Rub:

  • Truff hot sauce (binder)
  • 1/2 Tbsp granulated garlic
  • 1 Tbsp fresh cracked black pepper

Wellington:

  • 2 Tbsp prepared horseradish
  • 2 Tbsp Dijon mustard
  • 700 g brown cremini mushrooms
  • 5 garlic cloves
  • 2 tsp smoked sea salt
  • 2 tsp fresh cracked black pepper
  • 6 roasted chestnuts
  • Prosciutto, enough to wrap the roast
  • Puff pastry
  • 1 egg, beaten

Optional:

  • Bourbon for the sear
  • Thyme herb smoke bomb

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Dry brine the chateaubriand overnight.
  2. Render beef fat with garlic, chestnuts, truffles, thyme, and water; strain and inject.
  3. Season with the rub and sear (optionally with bourbon); cool.
  4. Pulse mushrooms, garlic, chestnuts, salt, and pepper; cook down to a dry duxelles.
  5. Brush roast with horseradish and mustard, wrap in prosciutto and duxelles, then in puff pastry.
  6. Egg-wash and bake until pastry is deep golden and center reaches desired doneness.
  7. Rest before slicing.

docs.text: • Method is inferred from the ingredient list and standard Wellington technique.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A repeatable brisket approach built around overnight dry brine, tallow injection, and a steady double-indirect smoke.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Recipe type: BBQ brisket
  • Cuisine: Texas-style BBQ
  • Prep time: 30 minutes + overnight dry brine
  • Cook time: low and slow (varies by size)
  • Total time: 1-2 days
  • Serves: depends on brisket size
  • EGG setup: double indirect
  • EGG target temperature: low and slow

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Brisket:

  • 1 beef brisket

Dry brine:

  • 1 Tbsp granulated garlic
  • 2 Tbsp + 2 tsp kosher salt
  • 4 tsp Lawry's (or copycat, see below)
  • 4 Tbsp ground black pepper

Injection:

  • 2 cups water
  • Beef fat trimmings from brisket

Optional: Lawry's alternative

  • 2 Tbsp kosher salt
  • 2 tsp white sugar
  • 3/4 tsp paprika
  • 1/4 tsp ground turmeric
  • 1/4 tsp onion powder
  • 1/4 tsp garlic powder
  • 1/4 tsp cornstarch

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Trim brisket and reserve fat for tallow.
  2. Apply the dry brine and rest overnight.
  3. Render fat with water for a light tallow injection; inject the flat.
  4. Set up the EGG for a clean, double-indirect fire and stabilize low and slow.
  5. Smoke, adjusting airflow based on probe data and bark development.
  6. Use a foil boat once the bark is set to push through the stall.
  7. Rest thoroughly before slicing.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Method steps are condensed from the Brisket 101 page and its cooking plan.
  • Adjust temps and timing to your brisket size and cooker behavior.

docs.text: A hearty, cheese-forward lasagna built with ricotta, mozzarella, parmesan, and a beefy tomato sauce.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• Recipe type: Baked pasta
  • Cuisine: Italian-American
  • Prep time: 25 minutes
  • Cook time: 45-60 minutes
  • Total time: 1.5 hours
  • Serves: 8-10
  • EGG setup: indirect
  • EGG target temperature: moderate baking heat

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Cheese layer:

  • 32 oz (900 g) ricotta cheese
  • 1 lb (450 g) fresh mozzarella
  • 16 oz (450 g) low moisture mozzarella
  • 2 cups grated parmesan
  • 2 eggs
  • 1/4 cup fresh basil

Meat sauce:

  • 1.5 lb (680 g) ground beef, browned
  • 2 Tbsp garlic, minced
  • 2 cups pasta sauce
  • 1 can stewed tomatoes
  • 1 Tbsp Italian seasoning
  • 1 Tbsp garlic powder

Pasta:

  • 1 package lasagna noodles

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Mix ricotta, eggs, basil, and half the parmesan.
  2. Combine browned beef with garlic, pasta sauce, stewed tomatoes, and seasonings.
  3. Layer sauce, noodles, ricotta mixture, and mozzarella in a greased baking dish.
  4. Repeat layers and finish with remaining mozzarella and parmesan.
  5. Bake until bubbling and the top is well browned; rest before slicing.

docs.title: Method

1. Toast and lightly crush the pickling spices.
  2. Mix the brine, chill, and submerge brisket for several days.
  3. Rinse, pat dry, and apply the rub.
  4. Smoke indirectly until the bark is set and the brisket is tender.
  5. Rest, slice thin, and serve.

docs.text: Reverse-seared picanha for a Brazilian steakhouse-style roast on the Big Green Egg.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 2.5 lb (1.1 kg) picanha roast
  • BBQ rub (or salt, pepper, and garlic)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Preheat the Big Green Egg to 250 F (121 C) using a two-zone setup.
  2. Trim the silver skin and extra fat from the meat side of the picanha.
  3. Crosshatch the fat cap.
  4. Season both sides with your rub.
  5. Grill the roast on the indirect side until the internal temperature reaches 120 F (49 C).
  6. Open the vents to bring the direct side to about 500 F (260 C).
  7. Sear fat side down for 90 seconds, then fat side up for 90 seconds.
  8. Rest for 10 minutes, slice, and serve.

docs.title: Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 24 (about 150 g portions using a 7.3 kg roast)

  • Prep time: 75 minutes
  • Cook time: 4-6 hours
  • Total time: 7 hours 15 minutes
  • EGG setup: indirect smoke
  • EGG target temperature: 225-250 F (107-121 C)

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 3.6-7.3 kg beef ribeye roast

Herb paste:

  • 59 ml olive oil
  • 28 g kosher salt
  • 28 g freshly ground black pepper
  • 14 g finely chopped fresh rosemary
  • 14 g finely chopped fresh thyme
  • 14 g finely chopped fresh sage

Garnish:

  • 14 g finely chopped fresh parsley (optional)

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Combine the herb paste ingredients and spread evenly over the roast at least 1 hour before cooking. Bring the roast to room temperature before it goes on the EGG.
  2. Preheat the smoker to 225-250 F (107-121 C).
  3. Add wood chunks or pellets for smoke as desired.
  4. Insert a thermometer into the thickest part of the roast without touching bone or fat. Place the roast rib side down and smoke for 4-6 hours, or until the internal temperature reaches 135-140 F (57-60 C) for medium rare or 155 F (68 C) for medium.
  5. Rest under a foil tent for 15-20 minutes (the temperature will rise about 5F).
  6. Carve between the ribs. For thinner slices, remove the ribs first.
  7. Season with salt and parsley as desired.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• For medium rare, pull at 135-140 F (57-60 C). For medium, pull at 155 F (68 C).
  • Leftovers portion well for sandwiches or ready-to-eat meals.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen Steak Reverse Sear Method
Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
• EGG setup: indirect, then direct for sear
  • EGG target temperature: 225 F (107 C) indirect, 550 F (288 C) for sear

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Steak:

  • The Four Saucemen The Beef Rub
  • Best steak you can buy (tomahawk rib eyes are great for a party)
  • Flaky sea salt, to season
  • Olive oil, for coating

Steak butter:

  • 250 g butter
  • 1 large shallot, finely diced
  • 2 cloves garlic, minced
  • 1/2 cup flat-leaf parsley, finely chopped
  • 1/4 cup sage, finely chopped
  • 1/4 cup tarragon, finely chopped
  • 1/2 tsp finely grated lemon zest
  • 1 tsp ground black pepper
  • Salt, to taste

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Mix the steak butter ingredients. Roll in food wrap into logs and freeze what you do not need.
  2. Set up the Big Green Egg for indirect cooking at 225 F (107 C) with two pieces of smoking wood.
  3. Cook the beef from room temperature. Coat lightly with olive oil and apply a fine layer of beef rub 10 minutes before grilling.
  4. Once the EGG is stable at 225 F (107 C), place the steak in the center of the grill. Turn every 10 minutes.
  5. For a 6 cm thick steak, expect about 45-50 minutes to reach medium-rare. Target internal temperatures: 115-120 F (46-49 C) rare, 125-130 F (52-54 C) medium rare, 135 F (57 C) medium.
  6. Remove the steak and rest under a tented foil.
  7. Carefully remove the ConvEGGtor. Open the vents and heat the EGG to 550 F (288 C). Preheat cast iron or grill grates if you have them.
  8. Sear the steaks for 1 minute per side, turning at 30 seconds for diamond marks.
  9. Top with steak butter while resting and season with flaky sea salt if needed.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Reverse sear works best for steaks thicker than 3 cm, especially scotch fillet or rib eye.
  • The recipe does not recommend cooking past medium.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Cheeks
Overview
docs.text: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Cheeks

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Beef Rub
  • 2-6 beef cheeks
  • Olive oil (binder)
  • Foil tray large enough for the cheeks
  • Foil to cover the tray
  • Dark beer
  • Beef broth
  • 1 onion, chopped
  • One great bottle of red for the chef

docs.title: Spritz
docs.text:
• 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

Mix in a spray bottle.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Open a beer (repeat if necessary) and a good bottle of red to breathe.
  2. Set your BBQ or smoker for indirect cooking at 250-275 F (121-135 C) with two pieces of smoking wood. We used Pohutukawa.
  3. About 30 minutes before smoking, trim any silver skin and hard fat from the cheeks.
  4. Lightly coat with olive oil and apply The Four Saucemen Beef Rub on all sides.
  5. Place the cheeks on the BBQ (use a drip pan). Smoke uncovered for 2.5 hours for small cheeks (about 500 g) or about 4 hours for large cheeks (about 1 kg). Spritz every hour.
  6. The cheeks should be dark brown. If using a probe thermometer, expect around 150-160 F (66-71 C).
  7. Prepare a foil tray with dark beer, beef broth, and chopped onion (wine, port, or beef stock also work). You want 15-20 mm of liquid in the base. Use room-temperature liquids.
  8. Place the cheeks in the tray, cover tightly with foil, and braise. If using a Bluetooth thermometer, insert it before covering.
  9. Return the tray to the BBQ until the internal temperature reaches about 210 F (99 C), usually 2.5-4 hours depending on size.
  10. Carefully uncover and check doneness. The probe should slide in with almost no resistance. For slicing, cook until about 205 F (96 C) instead.

These are great for tacos, quesadillas, or served with a simple salad. This method also works for beef shin.

docs.title: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Short Ribs
Overview
docs.text: The Four Saucemen BBQ Beef Short Ribs (8-9 hour cook)

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Beef Rub
  • Beef short ribs (Wakanui, Ocean Beef, Silver Fern Farms Reserve, or similar)
  • Olive oil (binder)

docs.title: Spritz
docs.text:
• 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

Mix in a spray bottle.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Open a beer (repeat if necessary).
  2. Remove the ribs from the fridge and bring to room temperature.
  3. Trim the top side to expose the meat under the fat. Remove any silver skin.
  4. Set your Big Green Egg or smoker for indirect cooking at 250-275 F (121-135 C) with two pieces of smoking wood. We used Pohutukawa for beef.
  5. About 10 minutes before smoking, apply a thin layer of olive oil and a light coat of The Four Saucemen Beef Rub.
  6. Place the ribs on the Egg, bone side down. Smoke uncovered and spritz every 1.5 hours.
  7. Cook until internal temperature is around 200 F (93 C), about 8-9 hours. Probe with a bamboo skewer; it should feel like very soft butter with little resistance.
  8. Once it probes tender all over, cook for another hour.
  9. Remove and rest for 10 minutes.

Beef short ribs are extremely fatty and delicious. A chimichurri (Jess Pryles recipe) is a great dressing to cut through the richness.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Four Saucemen Brisket Steps ("The Holy Grail of BBQ")

This recipe is designed for a 6-10 kg brisket.

docs.title: Choosing Your Brisket
docs.text: There is now a great selection of brisket available in NZ: small to large, grass-fed, grain-finished Wagyu, Aussie imports, and USA briskets. Look for good fat, marbling, and a thick flat. If you are unsure, ask your butcher. The point end is fatty and forgiving; the flat is where most of us get frustrated.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• The Four Saucemen Beef Rub
  • 1 large whole brisket (Snake River Farms USA, Wakanui NZ, Ocean Beef NZ, First Light NZ, or Black Onyx AUS)
  • Olive oil (binder)
  • Foil tray large enough to fit the brisket
  • Foil to cover the tray or quality peach paper
  • Dark beer
  • Beef broth or stock
  • 1 onion, chopped
  • One great bottle of red for the chef and a couple of beers for good measure

docs.title: Spritz
docs.text:
• 1 part Worcestershire sauce
  • 1 part clear apple juice
  • 1 part apple cider vinegar
  • 1 part water

Mix in a spray bottle.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Open a beer (repeat if necessary) and a good bottle of red to breathe. Every brisket varies by breed, fat content, and size.
  2. Set your BBQ or smoker for indirect cooking at 250-275 F (121-135 C) with smoking wood. We used oak in a Lonestar Grillz offset and hickory on a Big Green Egg. If your brisket looks lean, run a lower temp.
  3. Allow the brisket to come to room temperature (this can take hours). Trim any silver skin and hard fat, leaving the softer fat to protect the meat. About 30 minutes before cooking, lightly coat with olive oil and apply The Four Saucemen Beef Rub on all sides.
  4. Smoke uncovered for about 4 hours. Fat side up on an offset, fat side down on the Big Green Egg. Use a drip pan. Spritz every hour. The bark should be dark brown and set (it should not smudge when you gently rub it). Internal temperature is typically around 150-160 F (66-71 C) at this stage.
  5. Prepare a foil tray with dark beer, beef broth, and chopped onion (wine, port, or beef stock also work). You want 15-20 mm of liquid in the base, and the liquids should be room temperature. Place the brisket in the tray, insert a temp probe if using one, and cover tightly with foil. Alternatively, wrap in quality peach paper with some of the liquid and onion.
  6. Return the covered brisket to the smoker. When internal temperature reaches around 200 F (93 C), start checking the feel.
  7. Probe with an instant-read thermometer. It should slide in like room-temperature butter with little resistance. Check the point and the flat. Internal temps can vary from 200 F to 215 F (93-102 C); feel matters most.
  8. Rest: Unwrap and let the brisket sit in the juices so steam can escape (at least 15 minutes). Rewrap, cover with a towel, and rest in a cooler/chilli bin/esky for about 2 hours if you can wait.
  9. Slice the flat across the grain. Use the point for burnt ends or slices.

Brisket is extremely versatile: burgers, soups, pies, pizza topping, or freshly sliced on white bread with a little reduced gravy and mustard.

docs.title: Tri Tip with Blue Cheese Smoked Paprika Butter
Recipe Essentials
docs.text:
Serves: 8

  • Prep time: 10 minutes
  • Cook time: 40 minutes
  • Total time: 50 minutes
  • EGG setup: indirect, then direct for sear
  • EGG target temperature: 350 F (177 C) indirect, 500-600 F (260-316 C) for sear

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
• 1.7 kg tri tip
  • Freshly ground NY cut pepper
  • Flaky sea salt or kosher salt (smoked sea salt works too)
  • Smoked paprika
  • Garlic powder
  • Optional: your favorite rub

Blue cheese smoked paprika butter:

  • 4 oz (115 g) blue cheese
  • 1 stick butter, softened
  • Fresh ground pepper
  • 1 tbsp smoked paprika

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Prepare the EGG for 350 F (177 C) indirect heat using the deflector.
  2. Season the tri tip with salt, pepper, garlic, paprika, or your favorite rub.
  3. Smoke on indirect heat for 20-30 minutes, until internal temperature reaches 120-127 F (49-53 C).
  4. Rest under a foil tent.
  5. Raise the EGG temperature to 500-600 F (260-316 C) and sear each side for about 2 minutes, aiming for 127-130 F (53-54 C) for medium rare.
  6. Rest for 10 minutes, slice, and serve with the blue cheese butter.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The thinner end cooks faster; monitor internal temperature closely.
  • This roast is best cooked to medium rare rather than well done.

docs.title: Ingredients
docs.text:
Chicken:

  • 2-3 lb (0.9-1.4 kg) chicken drumsticks

Seasoning:

docs.text:

  • 24 wooden or stainless steel skewers (2 per thigh, hibachi style)
  • Duck fat spray (or any neutral oil spray)
  • Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

Gochujang basting:

  • 113 g gochujang (Korean chili paste)
  • 133 ml soy sauce
  • 56 g honey (or agave nectar)
  • 56 g rice wine vinegar
  • 2 g kosher salt
  • 4 g freshly ground black pepper
  • 1 green apple, peeled
  • 1 nashi pear, peeled
  • 50 g fresh pineapple (optional)
  • 18 g garlic cloves
  • 18 g fresh ginger, peeled
  • 1 small red onion, finely diced
  • Water, as needed to loosen

Garnish:

  • 1 scallion, finely sliced
  • 1 sprig fresh coriander, leaves only
  • 5 g toasted sesame seeds

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. If using wooden skewers, soak in water for at least 30 minutes.
  2. Trim any cartilage from the thighs. Season with salt, pepper, and a light spray of duck fat.
  3. Thread each thigh on two skewers about 25 mm apart. Refrigerate on a tray until ready to grill.
  4. Blend gochujang, soy sauce, honey, vinegar, ginger, and garlic until smooth.
  5. Add apple and pear; blend again until smooth. Add pineapple if using.
  6. Stir in diced red onion. Add a splash of water if you need to thin the basting.
  7. Preheat charcoal to 390-400 F (200 C). Hibachi, yakitori, or kettle grills work well.
  8. Grill thighs, turning once they color. Begin basting after the first flip.
  9. Continue flipping and basting until the internal temperature reaches 159 F (70 C).
  10. Rest 3-5 minutes, then garnish with scallion, coriander, and sesame seeds.

  • 1/2 small shallot, finely minced
  • 60 ml soy sauce
  • 10 ml fresh orange juice
  • 60 ml fresh lime juice
  • 3 Tbsp honey

  • 1 tsp ground cumin
  • 1 tsp smoked paprika

docs.text:

Spritz:

  • 1 L clear apple juice
  • 150 ml apple cider vinegar
  • 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce
  • 1.5 L spray bottle

Rub (optional) or use your favorite rub (The Four Saucemen Pork Rub):

  • 1 1/2 tbsp sweet smoked paprika
  • 1 tbsp paprika
  • 1 1/2 tbsp kosher salt (do not use iodized table salt)
  • 2 tsp cracked black pepper (avoid fine white pepper)
  • 2 tsp garlic granules
  • 2 tsp onion powder
  • 1 tsp ground cumin

docs.title: Method
docs.text:
1. Make the rub: Combine all dry ingredients except the brown sugar and kosher salt. Sift once, then sift again while adding the brown sugar. Add the kosher salt at the end and mix thoroughly.
  2. Set up your pit or BBQ for indirect cooking at 250 F (121 C).
  3. Trim only hard fat and remove any skin if needed.
  4. Rub mustard over the pork, then apply the rub generously.
  5. Mix the spritz ingredients in the spray bottle and shake well.
  6. Add wood chunks to the fire. When the smoke thins to a light blue haze, place the pork on the grill. Cook 6-7 hours until the bark is dark. Start spritzing after the first 3 hours, then spritz every 45-60 minutes.
  7. When the internal temperature reaches about 170 F (77 C), wrap. Lay two sheets of foil in a cross, spritz the pork, then wrap tightly and seal.
  8. Return to the pit/BBQ and cook another 2-3 hours until the internal temperature reaches 199-203 F (93-95 C).
  9. Rest wrapped in a cooler or warm place for 1-2 hours.
  10. Unwrap in a foil tray, pour in the juices, remove the bone and cartilage, then pull the meat. Toss with the juices and serve with Carolina mustard BBQ sauce, pickles, and buns.

docs.title: Method
docs.text:

  8. Heat oil in a deep fryer or heavy pot to 355 F (180 C).
  9. Fry dried pork squares in batches for 2-4 minutes, until puffed and floating. Drain on a wire rack with paper towels and season with salt immediately.
  10. Serve warm with a drink of your choice.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: A step-by-step process for lighting, stabilizing, and cleaning a Big Green Egg.

docs.title: Process
docs.text:
1. Open the top and bottom vents as wide as possible.
  2. Fill lump charcoal to the top of the inner firebox ceramic (to the bottom of the split between the firebox and fire ring).
  3. Light the charcoal using organic fire lighters or an electric blower. If using fire lighters, place three around the charcoal, light them, build a small teepee of charcoal, and leave the lid open for maximum oxygen. If using an electric blower, hold it about 1 inch away from the charcoal for about 4 minutes.
  4. With the charcoal lit and the lid open, insert the ConvEGGtor legs down to preheat it.
  5. As the temperature climbs to about 20 F (11 C) below target, close the top and bottom vents halfway. Wearing heat gloves, flip the ConvEGGtor so legs are up, add the cooking grid, and close the lid.
  6. Let the EGG settle. When it starts to rise above target, close the vents by another 50 percent (about 25 percent open). Let it stabilize again.
  7. Once stable, close the vents to about a finger-width (or slightly less).
  8. The EGG should hold temperature for the entire cook.
  9. When the food reaches the desired internal temperature, remove it and close the vents to extinguish the fire.

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Before the next cook, use the ash tool to knock charcoal around, clear ash into the bottom chamber, and rake it out. The ash will be cold the next day and can be used in the garden.
  • For roasts, use a roasting pan to avoid mess on the ConvEGGtor. For ribs, steaks, or thighs, place foil over the ConvEGGtor to catch drips.
  • Clean the grill by washing and drying. For ceramics, never use water; brush them down so ash drops into the charcoal.
